The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services in order to  relieve suffering and improve living conditions in communities across Kenya.

loans.use: to buy more stock for his grocery business

loans.name: Oliva

texts.en:
Oliva is a member of the Frelimo borrower group  in Ilala,Iringa,she is 48 years old woman,she is separated from her husband,she is  a mother of 4 children are children are aged 30,26,23 and 19 years.

 Oliva started he own business selling bites 3 years ago,she works 8 hours a day and earn and earn monthly profit approximately 200,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is Oliva second loan from BRAC_Tanzania,she requested the amount of 350,000 Tsh in order to buy more wheat flower,cooking oil for sale.

With the profit she gains from the use of this loan Oliva hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more wheat flower,cooking oil

loans.name: Iyabo

texts.en: Iyabo is 41 years old and married with four children.  She resides in Lagos State, Nigeria, where she sells frozen food (chicken, turkey and fish).  She has been in this business for the past five years. She has been engaged with LAPO microfinance for the past three years. Iyabo is requesting a loan of N150,000 to purchase more frozen food and expand her shop to meet her customers demands. She thanks Kiva lenders and LAPO microfinance for the financial support.

loans.use: to purchase more frozen food to sell

loans.name: Discipline Plus Group

texts.fr:
Donatien K. 39 ans, est dirigeant d’un groupe composé de 25 emprunteurs unis solidairement pour recevoir des prêts de Kiva à travers Hope RDC en vue de développer leurs activités. Cette banque communautaire s’appelle « Discipline Plus». Lui et son groupe ont déjà reçu deux fois les prêts de Hope RDC et les ont remboursés correctement.
Donatien est couturier de profession depuis 1990. Il aime son métier et a acquis une solide expérience en l’exerçant pendant plusieurs années. Le capital initial qui lui avait permis d’ouvrir son atelier était de $120. Son atelier se situe un peu à l’ouest de Kinshasa. Donatien est bien connu dans son quartier à cause de ses services de qualité et de bonnes relations avec ses clients. Il est client fidèle de Hope RDC. Son plan avec le prochain prêt est d’acheter des doublures, des boutons et autres accessoires pour satisfaire le besoin de ses clients et ainsi accroitre le revenu de son affaire. Son ambition est d’ouvrir une maison commerciale d’articles de couture. Donatien est célibataire mais père de deux enfants âgés de 3 et 10 ans. Un seul est scolarisé.

loans.use: acheter des doublures, boutons et autres accessoires pour satisfaire le besoin de ses clients et accroitre le revenu

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Folusho

texts.en:
Folusho is single lady, 26 years old; she lives in Lagos State, Nigeria. She has sold stationery and books for over seven years.

Folusho has been with LAPO Micro-finance for the past three years and she is requesting a loan of N120,000 to purchase more stationery to sell. She says thanks to LAPO Micro-finance and to all Kiva lenders for the financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more stationery to sell

loans.name: Carmelita

texts.en:
Carmelita T. is from the city of Dipolog. She is 61 years old. Carmelita is married and has 2 adult-aged children. To make a living, Carmelita owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops and livestocks. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting & harvesting  a variety of vegetables, and raising pigs for sale. Carmelita has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Carmelita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Carmelita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. Carmelita is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to purchase feeds for her raised pigs, and construction materials for house repair. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Carmelita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase a transport vehicle to improve the business

loans.name: Bat-Erdene

texts.en:
Bat-Erdene B. is a 26-year-old single lady. She lives with her parents in the Chingeltei district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia.

Bat-Erdene graduated from a local technical college in 2006 with a degree in electrical engineering. In spite of her degree in engineering, she started a small convenience store business in early 2008. Her convenience store is located in a busy suburban area of the city; therefore, her business does pretty well.

Bat-Erdene mostly purchases her inventory of food products from Ulaanbaatar's various wholesale markets, where she is able to find the best deals in the city. Some of the food products are delivered by the producers. The selling volume usually peaks during national holidays and in the fall when school starts.

As school starts in September, Bat-Erdene requests a loan to stock up her food inventory in order to get ready for the peak season for her business.

loans.use: To stock up her food inventory

loans.name: Budragchaa

texts.en:
Budragchaa B. is 56 years old and the father of three grown-up children. He currently lives with his wife and three children (ages ranging between 21 and 26) in the Chingeltei district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia.

Budragchaa is a talented maker of picture-frames for drawings and portraits. He has been making various frames by hand since 1997. Most of his customers are artists who would like to put their work in exhibitions. They usually purchase frames from Budragchaa for their drawings and portraits.

Since he is quite well-known among local artists for his artistic and beautifully-done frames, Budragchaa is mostly busy with orders. His business capital now exceeds 500,000 MNT ($1 USD = 1,450 MNT). He requests a loan to purchase raw materials for his business.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials for his business

loans.name: Aminat

texts.en: For the past ten years, Aminat has been a fashion designer and also sold tailoring materials. She is 34-years old and married with four children. She lives in Lagos State, Nigeria.  She has worked with Kiva partner LAPO Microfinance for more than one year.  Aminat is asking for a loan of NGN 150,000 in order to purchase more tailoring materials to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders for their financial support

loans.use: To purchase tailoring materials

loans.name: Sandagsuren

texts.en:
Sandagsuren D. is 37 years old and the father of a 9-year-old daughter. He currently resides with his daughter in Arhangai province, one of Mongolia’s central provinces. His daughter is a first grade student in a local high school.

Sandagsuren has been running a small bakery shop since 2001. He started his bakery business alone and, since then, his business has expanded and now employs three people. He mostly supplies his bakery products to nearby grocery and convenience stores. Since the start, his business has been quite successful and his business capital has increased from 200,000 MNT to 1,500,000 MNT (1 USD = 1,450 MNT).

In the near future, Sandagsuren would like to expand his business by making instant noodles for local customers. He sees a great potential for the product to be a success in the town. Sandagsuren requests a loan to purchase ingredients for his bakery business.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients for his bakery business

loans.name: Huong's Group

texts.en:
Hường Thị T. Nguyễn was born in 1980. She lives in Loc Ha hamlet, in Mai Lam, Dong Anh province, Hanoi, with her husband and her son. Her family runs a store where they sell irons, but Hường’s main job is farming. She also sells refreshers from home. Together they have a monthly income of about 4 million VND.

Hường is the leader of a five-member group that is applying for a loan from SEDA. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Hường wants to borrow VND 5,886,000 (approx. USD 345) to expand her store.

About the other borrowers in her group:

Ngân T. Thủy Nguyễn was born in 1982. She sells wooden furniture. She wants to borrow VND 5,450,000 (approx. USD 320) to buy wood.

Nguyện Thị P. was born in 1960. She wants to borrow VND 4,578,000 (approx. USD 265) to sell refreshers.

Hà Thị T. Trịnh was born in 1971. She wants to borrow VND 5,450,000 to buy goods to sell.

Mai Thúy Ngô was born in 1970. She is a hairdresser. She wants to borrow VND 5,886,000 to invest in her hairdressing shop.

loans.use: to expand store

loans.name: Mudupe

texts.en:
Mudupe is 49 years old and married with three children. She resides at Lagos State, Nigeria where she has sold provisions, drinks and foodstuffs for the past three years.

Having been with LAPO Microfinance for over a year, Mudupe hopes for the loan amount of N150,000 to purchase more provisions and foodstuffs to meet her customers’ demands. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions, drinks and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Glenda

texts.en:
Glenda T. is from the city of Dipolog. She is 23-years old, married and has one school-aged child. Glenda owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling clothing products in the local community. Glenda is just starting this business.

In 2007, Glenda joined Kiva partner PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Glenda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. Glenda is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Glenda from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase clothing

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina A. is a Tanzanian and a woman entrepreneur. She runs a food shop at Yombo Kilakala in Dar es Salaam. She purchases her business goods direct from the producers in wholesale, and some are purchased from the city food market at Kariakoo City Shopping Center.

Amina sells retail to her customers. Her business income is used to meet her daily family needs and to pay her children’s school fees. She needs a loan of Tshs 1,200,000 to capitalize her business.

loans.use: To buy more goods for her business

loans.name: Adijat

texts.en:
Adijat is a hair specialist and she also sells hair-cream and hair-extensions. She has been in this business for the past four years. She is 22 years old and married with a child. She resides at Lagos State, Nigeria.

Adijat has been with LAPO Microfinance for two years. She hopes for the loan of N50,000 to purchase more hair-extensions and hair-cream to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more hair-extensions and hair-cream to sell

loans.name: Opeyemi

texts.en:
Opeyemi is 45 years old and married with four children. She resides at Lagos State, Nigeria, where she sells provisions, drinks and foodstuffs.

Having been with LAPO Microfinance for over a year, Opeyemi is requesting the loan of N50,000 to purchase more provisions to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for the financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs and provisions to sell

loans.name: Juma

texts.en: Juma F. is a Tanzanian an entrepreneur small business married man. He runs a food shop business at Yombo Kiwani ward in Dar es Salaam. His purchases and sales varieties of crop food product including;  Maize flower, Wheat flower, Ground nuts , Beans, Sugar ang Cooking oil. He purchases direct from the producers in whole sales and selling in retail to customers. He has been in the business for seven years and the business income has enabled him to buy a plot in Dae es Salaam. He is requesting a loan of Tshs 1.200,000 to buy more business goods.

loans.use: To buy more business goods

loans.name: Yon's Group

texts.en: S., 43, is a mother of four children all whom are single and attend school. She married to Horn, 35, younger than her for years who owns a barber shop in the crowd place in the village. S. owns a groceries store selling food ingredients and other simple daily home usages to her neighbors. To match the demand for her selling, she decides to take a loan to invest the selling of her store. And the other rest three members are T. who also owns a groceries store, T. who runs a service as boat deliver, and N. who owns a shop selling food ingredient too.

loans.use: to invest the selling of her store.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more business goods

loans.name: Sebastiana

texts.en:
Sebastiana B. is from the city of Dapitan. She is 60 years old. Sebastiana is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Sebastiana owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Sebastiana has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Sebastiana joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Sebastiana has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase new items to expand product offering. Sebastiana is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 8th loan taken out by Sebastiana from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Rosina

texts.en: Rosina D. has been selling pots and pans in Abura since 2006. She has received no formal education.  She is married and has 4 dependents. Her husband is a steel bender. Rosina is responsible for paying for clothes and food. Her loan will be used to buy more pots and pans for resale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest.

loans.use: to buy more pots and pans for resale

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes O. is from the city of Dipolog. She is married, 31 years old, and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Agnes owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling cosmetic products in the local community. Agnes has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Agnes joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 2,500 PHP from PMPC. Agnes is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP. She wants her family to have their own appliances, and this loan will be used for a full payment on their installed TV and refrigerator. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Agnes from PMPC.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to fully pay for an installed TV and refrigerator

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce is a member of the Kajificheni borrower group in Ilala,iringa,she is 35 years old woman,she is married and a mother of 1 child,Her child is aged 21 years.

Joyce started her own grocery business 8 years ago,she works 12 hours and earn monthly profit approximately 30,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is Joyce first loan from BRAC_Tanzania,she requested the amount of 400,000 Tsh in order to buy more beer and soda.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan Joyce hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more beer,soda

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is fifty seven years old. She is wife and the mother of six children. currently only two of her children are in school the rest are married and have moved from the family house.. She is a retailer of charcoal and water in her community. Water is scarce in Mary's community and she was therefore motivated to dig a well which people come over to buy and use for their daily chores. Charcoal is a very popular source of energy for cooking in almost all the traditional Ghanaian homes. Mary obtains her supply of charcoal from the villages and retails them to her customers. She wants to use the loan to buy more supply of charcoal to increase her stock. She believes that she would be able to improve her income to support her kids who are in school.

loans.use: To buy charcoal.

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Comfort is forty-three years old and is the married mother of three children – two sons and a daughter. One child is in the senior high while the others are in the junior high and the primary school. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment. She is a very hard working woman and works to support her husband in taking care of the household.

Comfort runs a grocery store by the street, where she sells groceries such as Milo (a milk beverage), sugar, rice, candies, bread, etc. She has been in business for eight years now and wants a loan to buy more provision to expand her business. She is hoping to grow her business to enable her to provide a quality education to all her kids.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to expand her business

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en: Beatrice is 42-years old.  She is married and has given birth to four children, one boy and three girls. All the children are still in school. The family lives in a rented apartment. Beatrice sells soft drinks. She buys the drinks from wholesalers and sells them in a kiosk in her community. She has been in business for ten years and wants a loan to buy bulk assorted soft drinks in order to grow her business. Beatrice hopes to give all her children a quality education.

loans.use: To buy soft drinks

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn O. is from the city of Dipolog. She is 44 years old. Evelyn is separated and has 5 adult-aged children. To make a living, Evelyn owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting & harvesting  a variety of vegetables for sale. Evelyn has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Evelyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Evelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. Evelyn is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase construction materials to improve the borrower's house. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Evelyn from PMPC. She plans to have comfortable and presentable shelter to live. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase construction materials for house repair

loans.name: Edna

texts.en:
Edna is fifty years old. She is married and has given birth to two children: a son and a daughter. Her children have completed school and are working. She lives with her husband and niece in a rented apartment.

Edna trades in utensils and fabrics. She buys her goods from the central market in the city at wholesale prices and sells at the market square in her community. She has been in business for twenty years and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk. She aspires to grow her business and be able to support her family adequately.

loans.use: To buy goods in bulk

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en:
Hawa is a member of the Mwangata D borrower group in Ilala,Iringa,she is 50 years old woman,she is married and a mother of 5 children.Her children are aged 30,28,26,22 and 18 years. 

Hawa started her own business selling maize 3 years ago,she works 12 hours and earn monthly profit approximately 100,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is Hawa first loan from BRAC _Tanzania,she requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more maize.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan Hawa hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more maize for sale

loans.name: Stella

texts.en:
Stella is 43-years old, divorced and has three children who are currently in school. She has been responsible for her children since her husband left. Stella lives with her children in a family house.

Stella trades in various soft drinks and, for the past 12 years, has worked as a hair dresser. She is currently training four apprentices in her road side shop. At present, she buys her working materials, such as artificial hair, shampoo, pomades, creams, lotions, etc., from Accra central market. She is asking for a loan to buy these materials in bulk in order to be able to render quality services to her cherished clients. She aspires to grow her business and improve her family welfare.

loans.use: To buy products for a beauty salon

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice is the 45-year-old mother of five children who are currently in school. She is very supportive of her husband in taking care of the kids in school.

Beatrice trades in sewing accessories and has been doing this for the past five years. She sells items like lining material, sewing thread, school uniforms, lace and cloth. She wants to use the loan to buy more sewing items like linen, thread, thimbles, etc. in bulk to hedge against price increases. She hopes to increase her savings to support the kids in school.

loans.use: To buy more sewing items like linen, thread and thimbles

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en: Cecilia is a 47-year-old married mother of three school-aged children. She has been running a grocery store for the past 12 years. Her experience has made her a very successful trader. She sells items such as rice, sugar, vegetable oil, bottled water, body and hair creams, skimmed powdered milk, etc. She deems it a big opportunity to expand her business to include other items frequently demanded by her customers. Cecilia wants to use her loan to buy more bags of rice, bags of sugar, cartons of vegetable oil, boxes of body and hair creams etc., to grow her business and support her family.

loans.use: To buy groceries in bulk

loans.name: Chezalina

texts.en:
Chezalina is a member of the Mwangata D borrower group in Ilala,Iringa,she is 37 years old woman,she is married and a mother of 2 children. Her children are aged 18 and 13 years old woman,she also cares for other 2 dependents.

Chezalina started her own Tailoring  business 10 years ago,she works 12 hours a day and earn monthly profit approximately 100,000 Tanzania shillings. 

This is Chezalina`s first loan from BRAC_Tanzania,she requested the amount of 300,000 Tsh in order to buy more materials.

With the profit she gains from the use of this loan,Chezalina hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more materials

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en: Joyce is a 37-year-old married mother of four children – two daughters and two sons. She lives with her family in a family house. Joyce is a hardworking woman who runs a grocery store. She sells items such as coffee, Milo, flour, sugar, rice, candies, bread, etc. in a store by the street. Joyce has been in business for 18 years now and wants a loan to buy more groceries to expand her business. She hopes to give her children the best education she can afford.

loans.use: To buy more groceries

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret is a mother of two children, a boy and a girl, who are currently working. She is sixty years old and married. She lives with her husband in rented apartment in their community. She is a trader. She sells fresh fish in her community. She also supplies to retailers and food vendors in her community. Margaret buys cartons of fresh fish from the big cold stores in Accra. She has been in business for fifteen years and wants a loan to buy fish in bulk. She desires to grow her business and and be able to provide her kids with quality education.

loans.use: To buy fish in bulk

loans.name: Vida

texts.en: Vida is a 49-year-old married mother of three children, who are currently in school. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment. Vida is a hardworking woman who runs a grocery store. She sells items such as Milo, sugar, rice, candies, bread, etc. in a store on the street. She has been in business for 20 years now and wants a loan to purchase more groceries to grow her business. She is hoping to improve her standard of living and give her children the best education possible.

loans.use: To buy more groceries

loans.name: Asunta

texts.en:
Asunta is a member of the Frelimo B borrower group in Ilala,Iringa,she is 36 Years old woman,she is married and a mother of 2 children.Her children are aged 9 and 4 years.

Asunta started her own shop business selling rice,cooking oil,sugar 4 years ago.she works 12 hours a day and earn  monthly profit approximately 150,000 Tanzania shilling.

This is Asunta first loan from BRAC_Tanzania,she requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more sugar,rice.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan,Asunta hopes to save more money,pay school fees and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy  more sugar,cooking oil,rice

loans.name: Patience

texts.en: Patience is thirty seven year old woman. She is married with five children. Currently three of her children are in school the first two children are married and working.  She is a food vendor and sells banku and kenkey. Banku and kenkey are prepared from milled maize grains and it is taken with hot pepper or soup. She has many customers since it is enjoyed by many Ghanaian as breakfast, lunch and supper. She wants to use the loan to buy more raw materials like bags of maize, meat, fish, vegetables and firewood. She hopes to improve her income to support her children’s education.

loans.use: To buy food ingredieints

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en: Sarah is a 45-year-old widow and mother of three children – one daughter and two sons – who are currently in school. She lives with them in a rented apartment in a commercial town. Sarah is a hardworking woman who sells groceries such as Milo, biscuits, cooking oil, sugar, soap, etc. She has been in business for six years now and wants a loan to buy more groceries to expand her business. She is hoping to give her children the best education she can afford.

loans.use: To buy more groceries

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary A. sells sandals, shoes and clothing as a hawker in Abura. Mary has received no formal education.  She is married and has two children. Her husband is a welder. Mary has been selling sandals,  shoes and clothing since 2006. She is responsible for paying for clothing and feeding of the family. Her loan will be used to buy shoes, sandals and clothing for resale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest.

loans.use: Her loan will be used to buy shoes, sandals and clothing for resale.

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret is a 42-year-old married mother of two daughters, one of whom is in senior high school while the other is in junior high. She lives with her children and husband in a rented apartment in a commercial town. Margaret is a hardworking woman who works to support her husband take care of their household. Margaret runs a provision store by the street where she sells groceries such as Milo, sugar, rice, candies, bread, etc. She has been in business for five years now and wants a loan to buy more groceries to expand her business. Margaret believes in education and hopes to give her children the best education she can afford.

loans.use: To buy groceries in bulk

loans.name: Georgina

texts.en:
Georgina is 34 years old. She is married and has one child who is currently in elementary school. She lives with her husband and child in a rented apartment in their town. 

She is a trader, selling cassava and cereals such as maize, beans and gari. Georgina buys her goods from nearby communities at affordable prices and sells these items in the market square in her community. She is a supplier for food vendors and retailers. She has been in this business for eight years and requests a loan to buy goods in bulk. Georgina aspires to expand her business and sponsor her child’s education.

loans.use: To buy cereals in order to fund her child's education

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes' highest level of education is junior high school.  She is married and has no children. Her husband is a commercial driver. Agnes M. sells hair products and cosmetics in Abura.

Agnes has been selling hair products and cosmetics since 2007. She is responsible for paying for the house and managing home expenses. Her loan will be used to buy cosmetics and hair products for resale and also use at her beauty salon. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest in other funds.

loans.use: To buy cosmetics and hair products for resale and also to use at her beauty salon.

loans.name: Carmelita

texts.en:
Mrs. Carmelita B.'s dream is for her family to live a better life in Brgy. Carmelita is 38 years old and married to Mr. Francisco B.. Together, they are blessed with one child who is now attending college.

With a talent for business, Carmelita only needs an opportunity to test her entrepreneurial skills. This is how she convinced her husband to allow her to join the NWTF-Project Dungganon - so she could earn additional income for their small family. With the initial loans, she set up a "sari-sari" or general store which proved to provide a steady source of income for the family.

Because of her good performance as a member of the NWTF-Project Dungganon, she was able to access bigger loans which she used to invest in fishing. Later, she diversified these funds to purchase dried fish, locally known as "uga," which she delivered around the community. With three businesses that generate income for her, Carmelita's net profit averaged approximately PHP 5,000 per month.

This new loan of PHP 25,000 is Carmelita's 25th loan cycle, which she wants to use as additional capital to buy more fishing equipment. With her child already in college, Carmelita is determined to work harder and earn more to support the education of her only child. 

The attached picture shows Carmelita and Francisco B. inside of their "Sari-sari" or General Store.

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just a few women but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: To purchase additional capital for fishing equipment

loans.name: Bernadette

texts.en:
Bernadette M. is from Prk. Pag-unlad, Brgy.Ma-ao, Bago City Neg Occidental. She is 45 years old and married with two children of school age. Raising a family with two children with only one breadwinner in the family is very difficult. This is why Bernadette has decided to help her husband and use her innate talent at sewing by making and selling customized dresses to her neighbors and community.

Currently, Bernadette is borrowing PHP 10,000 to buy additional equipment for her tailoring and dressmaking business.

About NWTF:  
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just a few women but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon

loans.use: To purchase additional equipment for her tailoring and dressmaking business

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth A. sells shoes and slippers as hawker in Abura. Elizabeth has received no formal education.  She is a single parent and has 4 dependants. Elizabeth has been selling shoes and slippers since 2007. She is responsible for paying for feeding and clothing. Her loan will be used to buy slippers and sandals for resale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest.

loans.use: Her loan will be used to buy slippers and sandals for resale.

loans.name: Paul Mwangi

texts.en:
Paul W. is 36 years old, married to Ruth Wanjiru and have three little, beautiful children aged between three months to nine years old. His business is located along the Uganda Road in Eldoret Town. 

He has been working in the clothing business for the past seven years now. His business has been doing very well. 

Recently, Paul was introduced to KADET limited by an existing member. With this requested loan he hopes to use from KADET, he intends to add more stock to his shop - mostly trousers. In the future, he intends to improve his business and hopes to become a wholesaler.


About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions in communities across Kenya.

loans.use: To buy clothing, mostly trousers, for resale.

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en: Comfort A. is single and has received an education level up to primary school. Comfort sells cloth and materials in Abura, which she has done since 2006. Comfort uses her income to pay for housekeeping expenses. Comfort will use the requested loan to purchase additional cloth for resale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Comfort plans to reinvest these funds in her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional cloth for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Build a bedroom onto the front of the house

loans.name: Kike

texts.en: Kike is 40 years old and married with four children. She is a committed LAPO client. She is a seamstress and also sells tailoring materials ( items added to clothes in other to beautify it i.e. ribbons, linings, buttons, e.t.c.) she has been in business for eight years. She hopes for the loan of N100,000 to purchase tailoring materials to sell. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase tailoring materials to sell

loans.name: Iyabo

texts.en: Iyabo is 45 years old and married with four children. Her children assist her in her trade business when they are not in school. Iyabo sells drinks and has been in this business since 2004. She buys drinks from big distributors and sells to retail. Iyabo says she is requesting the loan of N140,000 in order to purchase directly from the company at a reduced rate. She says thank you to all who consider her situation and request.

loans.use: To purchase more crates of drinks to sell directly from the company.

loans.name: Akua

texts.en: Akua H. is a single parent and has two children. She has received education through the primary school level. Akua sells food supplies such as beans and groundnut at Takoradi, which she has done since 1978. Akua uses her income to pay for housekeeping expenses for her family. Akua will add the loan to her capital to buy more food supplies for resale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Akua plans to save.

loans.use: To buy more food supplies for resale.

loans.name: Erika

texts.es:
La señora Erika R. tiene poco tiempo que adquirió su vivienda por un crédito del gobierno. Pero solamente tiene construidos una recamara y son seis de familia. 
Es por eso que está solicitando un crédito para la construcción de un cuarto más a la casa y así  sus cuatro hijos tengan su propio espacio en la vivienda.
Doña Erika trabaja en limpieza de casa en diferentes partes, y su esposo el señor Julio Romero es empleado de una linia de trasportes en el departamento de mecánico eléctrico, estos son los ingresos que tiene para su familia y con el cual una parte los destinaran para el pago de préstamo.
texts.en:
Mrs. Erika R. acquired her home a short time ago through a government loan. The house has only one bedroom for her family of six. She is requesting this loan to add another bedroom to the house so that her four children have their own space in it.

Mrs. Erika works cleaning houses and her husband Mr. Julio Romero works for a transportation company in the department of electrical mechanic. The income from their jobs covers their family’s expenses and part of it will be used to repay this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Rina Paguaga, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Construction of an additional bedroom in their house

loans.name: Jacqueline

texts.fr: Jacqueline est née vers 1978 à Cotonou, Capitale Economique  de la République du Bénin. Jacqueline n’a jamais été à l’école. Jacqueline est mariée à Constant. Jacqueline a deux enfants et en plus de ses enfants, cinq personnes à charge. Jacqueline vit avec sa famille à Cotonou depuis huit ans. Jacqueline a scolarisé ses enfants et certains des enfants qu’elle a à charge.  Jacqueline supporte les charges familiales ensemble avec son mari.  Jacqueline est couturière de formation mais Jacqueline vend aussi de divers (Bonbons, biscuits, boîtes de lait, de sardines, de tomates, de sucres, les pâtes alimentaires, les savons de lessive, de vaisselle et de toilette, piles, bougies, etc.).  Jacqueline achète ses articles à Dantokpa, grand marché international du Bénin ;  et les revend chez elle à domicile à son atelier de couture. C’est depuis quatre ans que Jacqueline a ouvert son atelier et y vend en plus de la couture qu’elle fait, des divers. Jacqueline est à son quatrième crédit avec ALIDé. Jacqueline est un bon client qui rembourse très bien. Les crédits d’ALIDé ont permis à Jacqueline d’améliorer le niveau de son activité ainsi que sa vie et celle de sa famille. Jacqueline a pour ambitions de diversifier ses activités dans un futur proche.
texts.en:
Jacqueline was born around 1978 in Cotonou, the economic capital of the Republic of Benin. Jacqueline never went to school. Jacqueline is married to Constant. Jacqueline has two children, and in addition to her children, has five people in her care. Jacqueline has lived with her family in Cotonou for eight years. Jacqueline has sent her children, and some of the other children in her care, to school. Jacqueline pays for her family's expenses jointly with her husband. Jacqueline is a dressmaker by training, but she also sells various products (sweets, biscuits, cartons of milk, sardines, tomatoes, sugar, food pastes, soap for laundry, dishwashing, and personal use, batteries, candles, etc.). Jacqueline buys these items in Dantokpa, the grand international market in Benin, and resells them at her house in her dressmaking workshop. It has been four years since Jacqueline opened her workshop, where she sells various items in addition to the clothing she makes. Jacqueline is seeking her fourth loan through ALIDÉ (one of Kiva's field partners). Jacqueline is a good client who repays her loans very well. The previous loans obtained through ALIDÉ allowed Jacqueline to improve the level of her business as well as her life and that of her family. Jacqueline has the ambition of diversifying her business in the near future.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various items: biscuits, cartons of milk, sardines, tomatoes, sugar, food pastes, and soap for laundry, dishwashing, and personal use.

loans.name: Felipe

texts.es:
El señor Felipe H. ya ha tenido un crédito con FVP el cual pago puntual mente, nuevo mete está solicitando para el mejoramiento de su vivienda.
A su casa le hace falta los enjarres y pintura al exterior de ella, pero en esté momento el no cuanta con el dinero para realizar está mejora, es por eso que solicita un crédito. 
Don Felipe trabaja en el Palacio Municipal de Nuevo Laredo en el departamento de electricidad, dando mantenimiento al  alumbrado de la ciudad.
Este es el ingreso que genera para su familia y con el cual pagara el crédito
texts.en:
Felipe H. has had a loan with FVP, which he paid back punctually. He is asking for a new loan to improve his house. His house needs plaster and paint on the exterior. At this time he does not have the money to make this improvement. That is why he is asking for this loan. Felipe works en the Palacio Municipal in Nuevo Laredo in the electrical department, which performs maintenance on the city’s lighting. This generates income for his family, and it is what he will use to pay for the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For plaster and paint for the exterior of his house

loans.name: Mosunmola

texts.en: Mosunmola is 29 years old and married with two children. She lives in the state of Lagos in Nigeria. For the past five years, Mosunmola has been selling vegetable oil, kerosene and foodstuffs. Mosunmola has been with LAPO microfinance for the past one year and hopes to receive the requested loan amount of N150,000 to purchase more foodstuffs and kerosene to meet her customer demand. She says thanks to all KIVA lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs and kerosene to meet her customer demand

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther is 32 years old and married with two children. She lives in the state of Lagos in Nigeria. For the past five years, she has sold books, stationeries and drinks. Esther is requesting the loan amount of N 150,000 to purchase more books and stationeries to sell. She says thanks to all KIVA lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more books, stationeries and drinks to sell

loans.name: Edith

texts.fr: Edith est née vers 1977 à Porto-Novo, Capitale Administrative et Politique de la République du BENIN. Edith est mariée à Amorin, mécanicien-moto de formation et vendeur des postes récepteurs. Edith et Amorin ont un seul enfant et il est scolarisé. Edith a été à l’école mais elle s’est arrêtée au cours primaire. Ensemble avec son mari, Edith supporte les charges de la famille. C’est des condiments de cuisine que Edith vend ainsi que des sachets d’emballage mais comme activité secondaire.  Edith achète ses produits à Dantokpa, grand marché international du Bénin. C’est à son domicile que Edith vend les condiments ; les sachets, Edith les vend de façon ambulante. C’est depuis six ans que Edith est dans ces deux activités. Edith est à son quatrième crédit avec ALIDé et a toujours bien remboursé ses crédits. Les activités d’Edith connaissent plus ou moins d’évolution mais toujours est-il qu’elle rencontre la mévente de temps à autre. Edith souhaite bénéficier de l’appui financier d’ALIDé pour agrandir ses activités et les diversifier à la vente de fournitures scolaires.
texts.en:
Edith was born around 1977 in Porto-Novo, the administrative and political capital of the Republic of Benin. She is married to Amorin, a motorbike mechanic by training and a seller of radio receivers. Edith and Amorin have one son, who attends school. She attended school, but she stopped in primary school. Together with her husband, she is meeting family expenses. Sauce condiments are what she sells, as well as baggies for packaging, as her secondary business. She buys her goods in Dantokpa, the international grand marketplace of Bénin. She sells the condiments out of her house; the baggies are sold door-to-door. She has been in these two businesses for six years. Edith is on her fourth loan with ALIDé and has always repaid her loans. Her businesses are more or less improving. Yet it’s true she experiences a loss in sales from time to time. She wishes to benefit from financial support from ALIDé in order to expand her businesses and to diversify them by selling school supplies.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy bags for packaging and school supplies

loans.name: Bola

texts.en:
Bola is 43 years old and married with four children. She resides in Lagos state, Nigeria. She is a hair stylist and also sells hair extensions and hair cream. She has been in this business for twenty-three years.

Bola has been with LAPO microfinance for a year. She is requesting the loan of N150,000 to purchase more hair extensions and hair cream. She says thanks to Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions and hair cream to sell

loans.name: Luz Y Progreso Group

texts.en:
Elba M. M. (far right, second row) is the group coordinator for the Bank of Hope: Luz y Progreso (light and progress).

Elba owns her own beauty salon, which she operates out of her house. With this loan, she will be able to purchase more shampoo, conditioner, and other hair products so she can better meet the demands of her clients. Like many of Esperanza’s clients, Elba is a single mother and the sole breadwinner for her household. She looks forward to a brighter future of more stability and peace.

Following the Grameen model of microfinance, Esperanza primarily lends to groups. Thus, if one person in the group defaults, the others in the group are responsible. It is important that all members of the group know and trust each other. This community of women has an advantage in that they already know each other well and trust one another. Since they have this strong foundation, they can build from there, talking and planning about how to improve their businesses. As the coordinator, Elba is responsible for facilitating these conversations and making sure that all the women properly use their loans. 

On behalf of Elba, the Bank of Hope: Luz y Progreso, and the microfinance institute Esperanza International, thank you for providing opportunities for those who need them most.

loans.use: To buy more hair products including shampoo and conditioner

loans.name: Justina

texts.en: Justina C. is married and has 4 dependants. She has received schooling through junior high school. Justina has a small grocery store where she sells tin tomato and  cooking oil at Secondi near Takoradi, which she has done since 1996. Her husband sells cement blocks. Justina uses her income to pay for the family’s expenses. Justina will use the loan to purchase more groceries for resale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Justina plans to save.

loans.use: Justina will use the loan to purchase more groceries for resale.

loans.name: Omolayo

texts.en: Omolayo is 36 years old and married with 2 children. She live in Lagos state Nigeria. She sells eggs, provision and foodstuff. Omolayo has been in this business for over 2 years. She hopes for the loan amount of N150, 000 to purchase more provision and foodstuffs to sell. She says thanks to all KIVA lender and LAPO microfinance for financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more eggs, foodstuffs and provisions to sell

loans.name: Triunfadoras De Los Andes Group

texts.es: “Triunfadoras de Los Andes” un grupo unido y alegre, se reúnen cada catorce días en el Centro Focal del mismo nombre, se agruparon hace 10 años aproximadamente y vienen trabajando con optimismo y responsabilidad, cumpliendo sus reglamentos y los de la institución, además hacen uso de los servicios de Pro Mujer como la capacitación y visitando al consultorio. Actualmente su presidenta es María   López,  de 44 años de edad y vende comida hace 20 años ingresó al  grupo porque necesitaba comprar herramientas de trabajo y ahora necesita el préstamo para la comprar al por mayor  insumos como la papa, arroz y fideo a un costo menor. Las demás integrantes también cuentan con sus actividades económicas como la costura de ropa (chamarras, vestidos, sacones) otras elaboran peluches y  algunas cuentan con una tienda de barrio. Todas necesitan el préstamo para la compra de materia prima y mercadería.

loans.use: COMPRA DE INSUMOS, MATERIA PRIMA Y MERCADERIA

loans.name: Toyin

texts.en:
Toyin designs clothes of various styles in line with customers' demand. She also sells tailoring materials and has been in this business for the past four years, after training for two years. In her locality she is the only one selling tailoring materials hence the increased demand. She is requesting the loan of N140,000 to purchase more tailoring materials to sell.

Toyin is 35 years old and married with four children. She says thank you

loans.use: To purchase tailoring materials to sell

loans.name: Denise

texts.fr: Denise est née vers 1970 à Aïdjèdo à Cotonou, Capitale Économique de la République du Bénin. Denise est mariée à Donatien, agent de SOGEMA, société de gestion de Dantokpa, grand marché international du Bénin. Denise et son mari ont quatre enfants à charge tous scolarisés dont trois qui sont leurs propres enfants. Denise et sa famille vivent à Cotonou, depuis six ans. Denise supporte les charges de la famille avec son mari. Denise est alphabétisée et vend de friperies de façon ambulante depuis six ans. C’est à Dantokpa que Denise achète ses articles de friperies. Denise est à son quatrième crédit avec ALIDé et rembourse bien ses prêts. Denise sollicite ce prêt pour agrandir son activité.
texts.en:
Denise was born around 1970 in Aïdjèdo in Cotonou, the economic capital of the Republic of Benin. Denise is married to Donatien, an employee of SOGEMA, the trust company of Dantokpa, the grand international market in Benin. Denise and her husband have four children in their care, all of whom are in school, and three of whom are their own. Denise and her family have lived in Cotonou for six years. Denise provides for her family with her husband. Denise is literate and has been selling second-hand clothing door-to-door for six years. It is at Dantokpa that Denise buys her second-hand clothes. Denise is seeking her fourth loan through ALIDÉ (one of Kiva's field partners), and repaid all her previous loans well. Denise is seeking this loan to enlarge her business.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy bales of second-hand clothing

loans.name: Marlon Javier

texts.es:
En el Mercado Mayoreo de la ciudad de Managua el señor Marlon Javier G. se dedica a laborar por medio de la venta de productos varios en su propia pulpería que posee desde hace 2 años y que muy sabiamente ha venido desarrollando a medida que los años han venido transcurriendo.

Actualmente, el señor Marlon ha acudido a Ceprodel para solicitar un crédito para la compra de los productos a sus proveedores y por ello espera que su solicitud sea aprobada y así continuar con su negocio en su localidad logrando siempre la satisfacción de todos sus clientes.
texts.en:
Marlon Javier G. has a mini market in the Mercado Mayoreo in the city of Managua. He sells various products. He has worked in his store for two years. He has very wisely been developing his business through the years. Marlon currently has come to Ceprodel to ask for a loan to buy products from his providers. He hopes his request will be granted so that he can continue his business in his location, and, as always, satisfy all of his customers.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy products for his mini market

loans.name: Bukky

texts.en: Bukky is 30 years old and married with three children. She lives in Lagos State and has been in the wood business for three years. She says her husband works at this business with her jointly when not on the road, as he is a taxi driver also. Bukky hopes for the loan amount of N100,000 to purchase more wood to sell. She says thank you and promises to pay back promptly.

loans.use: To purchase wood to sell

loans.name: Karla Patricia

texts.es:
La señora Karla Patricia M. se dedica hoy en día a la venta de comida la cual es preparada por ella misma ofreciéndola en su establecimiento en la ciudad de Managua donde llegan a comprar los alimentos y sus clientes pueden sentarse en su casa de habitación a disfrutar la comida puesto que tiene un lugar amplio donde ofrecer dichos alimentos.

Es de importancia destacar que ella ha logrado salir adelante gracias a los créditos brindados por Ceprodel. Hoy en día ha solicitado un nuevo crédito con el propósito de invertirlo en la compra de la materia prima para elaborar los alimentos y así ofertarlos en su localidad en su propio establecimiento.

loans.use: Compra de materia prima para elaborar alimentos

loans.name: Carlos

texts.en:
Carlos is from the city of Quiindy. His own house is used for his business, selling products of prime necessity: breadmakers, meat of all kinds, etc. He is requesting credit for his operating capital, specifically to purchase merchandise to use in his business.

He is very grateful and pleased about the confidence that has been bestowed upon him, evident in the usefulness of the credit he received.

loans.use: to purchase merchandise

loans.name: Juan Manuel

texts.es:
El señor Juan Manuel C. es padre de familia y tiene dos hijos que actual mente están estudiando. 
Esta solicitando un crédito para comprar de las útiles escolares y el pago de la colegiatura ya que en este momento no cuenta con el dinero que le están pidiendo para que pueda inscribir a sus hijos en la escuela.
Don Juan Manuel es empleado de una Agencia Aduanal en el departamento de despachador y su esposa la señora Marcela Zamarrón se dedica a la limpieza de casa particulares. Estos son los ingresos que tiene para darles lo mejor a sus hijos y que puedan tener un buen estudio. Con una parte de los ingresos del señor Juan Manuel pagaran el préstamo. 
Cuando fuimos a visitar la casa de señor Juan Manuel el se encontraba en su trabaja, y su esposa también andaba en su empleo, y quien son atendió fue uno de sus hijos que es la persona que aparece en la foto
texts.en:
Juan Manuel C. has two children who are currently in school. He is asking for a loan to buy school supplies and pay school fees. He currently does not have the money that they are asking for to enroll his two children in school. Juan Manual works for the Customs Agency in the dispatch department. His wife, Marcela Zamarrón, cleans private homes. These are the incomes he has to give his children the best so they can have a good education. Juan Manuel will use part of the income to repay the loan. When the agency went to visit Juan Manuel’s house, he was working. His wife was also working. One of his sons was available, and he is the person in the photo.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy school supplies and pay school fees

loans.name: Alborada Group

texts.es:
En la ciudad de el Alto se encuentra ubicado el centro focal Villa Exaltación, a este pertenece la asociación "Alborada", formada por doce miembros que trabajan con mucho entusiasmo por mejorar en sus pequeños negocios.
Con la ayuda de sus familias se dedican a diversas actividades, por ejemplo: Elaboración y venta de muebles, elaboración de comida, venta de verduras,  chompas, frutas, otras tienen tiendas de consumo.  La asociación Alborada afirma que desean ampliar sus ventas, para esto necesitan reforzar su capital comprando mayor mercadería, tienen la seguridad que podrán generar mayores ganancias para el bien de sus familias.
texts.en:
The Villa Exaltación center is located in the city of El Alto. The Alborada association, which is comprised of twelve members who work enthusiastically to improve their small businesses, belongs to this center.

With the help of their family, these group members own different types of businesses, such as furniture manufacturing and sales, food sales, fruits and vegetables, sweaters, and general stores. The Alborada association members state that they would like to boost sales, but in order to do so, they need to reinforce their capital by purchasing more merchandise. They are sure that they will be able to generate more profits for the good of their families.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise

loans.name: Risikatu

texts.en: Risikatu sells spare parts in partnership with her husband whom she learnt this trade from. They have been in business for two years now and with it provide for their family's needs. Risikatu is 29 years old and has a child. She is requesting the loan amount of N140,000 to purchase spare parts in bulk so as to meet the demand of their customers. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase spare part to sell

loans.name: Olaïtan

texts.fr: Olaïtan est née le 27/12/1978 à Sakété dans le Département du Plateau au Sud du Bénin. Olaïtan est mariée à Essoun, un chauffeur. Olaïtan est mère d’un enfant, celui-ci a été scolarisé mais il est mort déjà. Olaïtan et son mari vivent depuis onze (11) ans à Cotonou, Capitale Économique de la République du Bénin. Olaïtan supporte les charges de la famille ensemble avec son mari. Olaïtan est Alphabétisée et vend des divers (boîtes de lait, de sardines, de tomates, de sucres, les pâtes alimentaires, les savons de lessive, de vaisselle et de toilette, piles, bougies, produits pour le thé, des beurres, des papiers hygiéniques, des mayonnaises, des insecticides, de laits et crèmes corporels, des produits pour les cheveux, pâtes dentifrices, etc.). Olaïtan est dans cette activité depuis cinq ans. C’est à Dantokpa, grand marché international du Bénin que Olaïtan achète ses articles et les revend chez elle à domicile. Olaïtan est à son cinquième crédit avec ALIDé et est un bon client qui rembourse très bien. Les crédits d’ALIDé ont permis à Olaïtan d’améliorer le niveau de son activité ainsi que sa vie et celle de sa famille. Olaïtan sollicite ce prêt pour renforcer son activité et mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.

loans.use: Achat de boîtes de lait, de sardines, de tomates, de sucres, les pâtes alimentaires, des papiers hygiéniques, de laits et crèmes corporels, des produits pour les cheveux et des pâtes dentifrices.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy supplies of sewing material such as linen, thread, thimbles, etc.

loans.name: Kwasi James

texts.en:
Kwasi James A. is a commercial driver at Anaji near Takoradi. Kwasi James has received education up to senior high school. He is married and has 6 dependents. His wife is a petty trader.

Kwasi James has been driving commercially since 1981. He is responsible for paying school fees and other bills. His loan will be used to purchase car spare parts to improve the efficiency of the car. He hopes to use the new profits from his business to educate his children.

loans.use: His loan will be used  to purchase of car spare parts

loans.name: 16 De Julio Group

texts.es:
Las integrantes del grupo “16 de Julio”, son personas que en su mayoría viven en la zona del mismo nombre y asisten a sus reuniones al Centro Focal “Los Andes”, cada dos semanas, ellas se agruparon por la necesidad de contar con un capital de trabajo que les permita mejorar sus negocios. 

Diversos son los negocios de las integrantes de “16 de Julio”, algunas se dedican a la  artesanía, produciendo prendas como carteras, sombreros y mantillas, los mismos están hechos a  mano utilizando cordeles o cola de rata, otras se dedican a la comercialización de productos vendiendo ropa, dulces y alimento.  

Todas necesitan el préstamo para la compra de materia prima como el cordel, o adquirir mayor mercadería para venderlo en el mercado.
texts.en:
The members of the group “16 de Julio” (July 16th) are mostly residents who live in the area of the same name. They meet at the “Los Andes” Community Center every 2 weeks. They have joined together because of their need for working capital to improve their businesses.

The members are engaged in different businesses. Some are involved in making handicrafts, producing items such as purses, hats, and blankets. These products are made by hand using rope or rat’s tail (a plant native to South America). Other members sell products such as clothing, candy and food.

They all need a loan to purchase raw materials, such as rope, or acquire more merchandise to sell in the market.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase materials & merchandise

loans.name: Grace Wairimu

texts.en:
Grace is 35 years old, and married with three children and she lives at Kirigu area in Kikuyu Town. Kirigu is a fast-growing center with many businesses and a relatively high population.

Grace got to know about KADET through her friend who was also a member. She has never borrowed from other sources, apart from KADET. When she took her first loan, she paid it off well and on time. This is her second loan and she plans to use this finances to buy a dairy cow.

Grace has been in dairy farming for a number of years now, and besides she also has 10 rental houses. Her customers for the milk are largely retailers in nearby kiosks while her tenants are the employed people working in the nearby towns. She hopes to own her own farm and add to the number of cows for more milk production up to about 10. This will enable her to get at least 80 litres of milk per day.

She also desires to add more rental houses to about 30. This will increase her monthly income, hence improve the standard of living of her family.

About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services in order to  relieve suffering and improve living conditions in communities across Kenya.

loans.use: Buying  a dairy cow

loans.name: Kuña Kyrey Group

texts.es:
In the city of Quiindy in the Bernardino C. neighborhood 23 km from the Carapeguá office, some women with limited resources that joined into the Mujeres Emprendedoras committee and decided to get together to receive information about the program mentioned.  

These active women, the majority of them dedicated to selling things and other activities mentioned above.  They are looking for a little more support to strengthen their families´ incomes and to better the quality of their lives through credit.  

They need this loan to invest in their respective jobs and with this they can attain sustainable growth that they will help them to grow as a group and as individuals. 

Some of the activities are: sale of milk, cheese, clothes,crafts, grocery store, dressmaker, etc.

loans.use: to invest in their respective jobs

loans.name: Firmine

texts.fr: Firmine est née le 10/10/1980 à Dangbo au Sud du Bénin. Firmine est mariée à Amigo François, un frigoriste. Firmine et François ont quatre enfants à leur charge, tous scolarisés. Firmine et sa famille vivent depuis quinze ans à Cotonou, Capitale Économique de la République du Bénin. Firmine supporte les charges de la famille ensemble avec son mari. Firmine n’est jamais allée à l’école. C’est des divers (boîtes de lait, de sardines, de tomates, de sucres, les pâtes alimentaires, les savons, les piles, les bougies, les produits pour le thé, des beurres, des papiers hygiéniques, des mayonnaises, des insecticides, de laits et crèmes corporels, des produits pour les cheveux, pâtes dentifrices, du riz en sac de cinq kilogrammes et des céréales, etc.) que Firmine vend chez elle à domicile depuis sept ans. Et c’est à Dantokpa, grand marché international du Bénin que Firmine achète ses articles. Firmine est à son cinquième crédit avec ALIDé et Firmine est un bon client qui rembourse très bien. Les crédits d’ALIDé ont permis à Firmine d’améliorer le niveau de son activité ainsi que sa vie et celle de sa famille. Firmine sollicite ce prêt pour renforcer son activité et mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Firmine was born on 10 October 1980 in Dangbo, in southern Benin. Firmine is married to Amigo François, a refrigeration technician. Firmine and François have four children in their care, all of whom are in school. Firmine and her family have lived in Cotonou, the economic capital of the Republic of Benin, for fifteen years. Firmine provides for her family together with her husband. Firmine never went to school. Firmine has been selling various products (cartons of milk, sardines, tomatoes, sugar, food pastes, soap, batteries, candles, tea products, butter, toilet paper, mayonnaise, insecticides, body creams and lotions, hair products, toothpaste, 5-kg bags of rice, cereals, etc.) at home for seven years. And it is at Dantokpa, the grand international market in Benin, that Firmine buys these items. Firmine is seeking her fifth loan through ALIDÉ (one of Kiva's field partners), and she is a good client who repays her loans well. Her previous loans through ALIDÉ have allowed Firmine to improve the level of her business as well as her life and that of her family. Firmine is seeking this loan to strengthen her business and better satisfy her customers.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cans of tomatoes, sugar, food pastes, toilet paper, body creams and lotions, toothpaste, oil stove wicks, yarn for weaving, and bags of rice, beans and manioc flour.

loans.name: Brujitas Group

texts.es: Catorce personas deciden conformar la asociación “Brujitas” se reunirán cada dos semanas en el centro focal Santiago II, a la cabeza de Lourdes Y. formaron el grupo entre vecinas y amigas de la zona. Necesitan capital para  iniciar sus negocios, estos son variados dentro este grupo, como ser; venta de cosméticos, confección de polleras, elaboración y venta de comida, venta de carne de res,  y otros. La asociación “Brujitas” necesita compra mercaderia.
texts.en:
Fourteen people make up the “Brujitas” group, which meets every other week in the center of Santiago II. Brujitas is the brainchild of Lourdes Y., who formed it among her neighbours and friends. This loan will help the members in their business ventures, which include selling cosmetics, making candy, preparing and selling food, selling beef, etc. The Brujitas group needs this loan to help them buy merchandise.

Translated from Spanish by Corinne Gilroy, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying merchandise

loans.name: Paulina

texts.en: Paulina is a wife and mother of three children who are currently in school. She is forty seven year old trader who trades in charcoal. Charcoal is very popular source of energy for cooking in many traditional Ghanaian homes. Paulina obtains her supply of charcoal from kintapo a town in the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana. She supplies to food operators and retails them to other households in her community. She wants to use the loan to buy more supply of charcoal to increase her stock. She believes the loan will enable her increase savings to provide the educational needs of her children.

loans.use: To buy charcoal.

loans.name: Robert Johnny

texts.en: Robert Johnny A. is a commercial driver at Takoradi. Robert Johnny has received no formal education.  He is married and has 7 dependents. Robert Johnny has been driving commercially since 1985. He is responsible for paying school fees and other bills. His loan will be used to buy car spare parts. He hopes to use the new profits from his business to educate his children.

loans.use: to buy car spare parts

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is a forty-year-old mother of four children who are currently in school. She is very supportive to her husband in taking care of the kids in school. She sells sewing accessories and has been doing this for the past six years. She sells items like lining materials, sewing thread, and school uniforms. She wants to use the loan to buy more sewing material like linen, thread, thimbles, etc. to increase her output and efficiency. She hopes to increase her savings to support the kids in school. She would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy sewing accessories

loans.name: Estela

texts.es:
la Sra. Estela S. se dedica a la venta y produccion de tortillas, ella es una persona de la tercedad y su unica fuente de ingresos es la produccion de tortillas.
este negocio le a ayudado mucho a salir adenlante y no depender de las remesas que le mandan sus hijas de españa.
su produccion a aumentado en estos ultimos 6 meses y contrato a una muchacha para ayudarle en su produccion, por tal razon esta solicitando el credito para poder comprar mas materia prima para tener una mayor produccion y cumplir con todas las exigencias de sus clientes.
Estela tambien vende sopa de mondongo todos los domingos, esta sopa es una comida muy tradicional de nuestro pais y es muy apetecida por los Hondureños, tambien con parte del dinero piensa comprar una olla muy grande para hacer la sopa, porque la que tiene es grande pero siempre se queda sin sopa rapido y pierde de vender.
ella nos comento que se siente muy feliz ya que todo le esta saliendo bien y que se entretiene mucho con su negocio, ya que como es una persona de edad no quiere estar sin hacer nada porque dice que se va a enfermar si solo esta descanzando.
texts.en:
Mrs. Estela S. works in the production and sale of tortillas. She is a determined person and her only source of income is the production of tortillas. This business has helped her greatly to get ahead and not depend on the remittances her daughters send from Spain. Her production has increased in the last six months and she hired a young woman to help with the production. This is the reason she is requesting a loan, to be able to buy more supplies to have an increased production and meet the demands of all her clients. Estela also sells mondongo soup on Sundays. This soup is a very traditional food of our country and is very much enjoyed by the Hondureños, Also, with part of the money she plans to buy a very large pot to make the soup since the one she has is big but she always runs out of soup quickly and loses sales. She commented to us that she is very happy now that everything is going well and she enjoys her business a great deal since she is an older person and does not want to be with nothing to do because she says she will become sick if she is just resting.

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Burke, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The purchase of corn flour, lime, firewood, and water

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Aminata Tiguidanké

texts.fr: Aminata Tiguidanké D. est une femme de 36 ans, elle est marié et mère de 06 enfants. Depuis six elle a ouvert une boutique à domicile où elle vend des produits divers. En moyenne, elle s'approvisionne en marchandises pour une valeur de 250000 francs CFA et réalise environs des bénéfices de 180000 francs CFA. Ces bénéfices lui serviront à aider son mari dans la prise en charge de la famille.
texts.en:
Aminata Tiguidanké D. is a young woman, 36 years old, married, and the mother of six children. Six ___ ago, she opened a shop in her home, where she sells various goods. Usually, she stocks up with merchandise worth 250,000 francs CFA, and she realizes a profit of 180,000 francs. She uses these profits to help her husband in supporting the family.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To bolster her self-financing ability

loans.name: Kojo Isaac

texts.en: Kojo Isaac M. is married and has 9 dependants. He has received schooling through junior high school. Kojo drives at Takoradi, which he has done since 1985. Kojo Isaac uses his income to pay for school fees and other bills. Kojo Isaa will use the loan to buy car spare parts. With the new profits from his expanded business, Kojo Isaac plans to educate his children.

loans.use: ojo Isaa will use the loan to buy car spare parts.

loans.name: Anthony

texts.en: Anthony I. is married and has 4 dependents. He has received no schooling. Anthony has been driving at Anaji near Takoradi, which he has done since 1991. His wife is a seamstress. Anthony uses his income to pay school fees and other bills. Anthony will use the loan to buy car spare parts for his car. With the new profits from his business, Anthony plans to start a building project.

loans.use: to buy car spare parts for his car

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret is 45 years old she is married and mother six children. Currently all her children are schooling. She is sells smoked fishes and started her fish sales ten years ago at community market where she lives. She buys stock of fish from Yeji in the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana and sells them on top of a table. She prepares and serves her customers with very tasty and good quality fish and because of that many customers buy from her stand. She buys stocks of fishes from the fish mongers. She has a high customer base that (customers) travels from the other part of the surrounding communities to buy her fish. She requests the loan to upgrade her stock of fishes. She dreams to give her children quality education through the proceeds from the business. She would be grateful for your support.

loans.use: To buy more stock of smoked fishes and dried fish.

loans.name: San Juan Group

texts.en:
In the city of Quiindy in the neighborhood of San Lorenzo, 23 km away from the Carapeguá office, live women with limited resources who joined the program Mujeres Emprendedoras committee and decided to get together to receive information about the mentioned program.

These are active women, the some of whom tailor-make clothes and are in sales, among other activities. They are looking for a little more support to strengthen their families’ incomes and to better the quality of their lives through credit. They need this loan to invest in their respective jobs, which will allow them to achieve sustainable growth as a group and as individuals.

Some of their activities are: sale of cheese, clothes, milk, silver jewelry, and food. Some of them have their beauty salon; others are dressmakers.

loans.use: to invest in their respective jobs

loans.name: Amatistas Group

texts.es:
En la ciudad de El alto se encuentra ubicado el centro focal Cascada, a este pertenece la asociación “Amatistas” formado por catorce  miembros que trabajan junto  a Pro-Mujer hace un año aproximadamente.
La mayoría de ellas son casadas y con familias numerosas. Existen varias actividades dentro el grupo, algunas tienen tiendas de barrio, otras de ellas  venden chompas y mantas tejidas a mano, Alfredo es cerrajero. La asociación amatistas necesita comprar mercadería para ampliar sus negocios, de esta manera generaran mayores ingresos para sostener económicamente a sus familias.

loans.use: COMPRA DE MERCADERIA

loans.name: Suma Chuyma Group

texts.es:
Maria Elena Q. es integrante del grupo “Suma Chuyma” que a su vez es parte del Centro Focal “Los Andes” ella tiene 34 años y hace 2 años inicio el negocio de costura de balones, esta actividad la aprendió de uno de sus tíos, vende su producto en diferentes ferias  tales como  la 16 de Julio, Tumusla y otros. Se animó a ingresar a “Suma Chuyma” por invitación a una de sus amigas y porque necesita el préstamo para comprar materia prima como el cuero y cuerina con los que elabora los balones.

Las demás integrantes del grupo también tienen sus propios negocios como la venta de muebles, lana, juguetes, ropa, verduras  y necesitan del crédito para comprar mercadería.
texts.en:
Maria Elena Q. is a member of the group "Suma Chuyma" (Good Spirit, in Quechua) which, in turn, is part of "Los Andes" focal center. She is 34 years old and started a business sewing soccer balls two years ago. She learned this work from her uncles and sells her products in different markets such as 16 de Julio, Tumusla, and others. She decided to join "Suma Chuyma" after receiving an invitation from one of her friends and because she needed a loan to buy raw materials used to make balls, such as leather and vinyl. The other group members also have their own businesses selling furniture, yarn, toys, clothing, and vegetables, and need loans in order to buy merchandise.

Translated from Spanish by Vivian Lu, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of raw materials (leather and vinyl) and merchandise.

loans.name: Pauline

texts.fr: Pauline est née le 22/11/1976 à Sègbohouè. Pauline est mariée à Henri, un photographe. Pauline et Henri ont six enfants à charge dont cinq qui sont leurs propres enfants. Certains de ces enfants sont scolarisés. Pauline supporte les charges de la famille avec son mari. Pauline est alphabétisée.
